speaker: SUPERVISOR
line: Hey, Ed. You okay?

speaker: EDWARD FUNSCH
line: There's blood.

speaker: SUPERVISOR
line: It's only a paper cut. Um, listen, Ed. I need to talk to you. There you go. Ed, uh... this is never easy. Ed, everybody down here sure likes you a lot, Funsch. And I know it's tough 'cause you're new to this area. Ed, I'm sorry, but I'm going to have to let you go. I mean, your work is first-rate, and like I said, you're a good guy. But you know the story. Cutbacks and seniority and... you're low man on the pole.

speaker: EDWARD FUNSCH
line: Could I work part-time?

speaker: SUPERVISOR
line: The guys took up a collection today. It's a hundred bucks. Look, why don't you stay on till the end of the week?

speaker: MESSAGE
line: Kill. "Robin Hull 326 Simpson Street Spring Valley, NY 10977" The read-out says "10977." "Jan Kobylka 2355 Mathers Ave. Pittsburgh, PA 15214" The read-out says "15214.") Kill. Kill 'em. Kill 'em all.
20 A.M. The elevator is crammed with various businessmen and women. One man has a nagging cough. Starting at eleven, the elevator goes down to seven when there is a ring and the door opens.)

speaker: WOMAN #1
line: Is there room in there for me?

speaker: MAN
line: Oh, I think we can make some.

speaker: WOMAN #1
line: Thank you.

speaker: WOMAN #2
line: Excuse me.

speaker: MESSAGE
line: No air. Can't breathe. Kill 'em all. Kill 'em.

speaker: SPENCER
line: Hey, Ralph, how you doing?

speaker: RALPH
line: All right.

speaker: SPENCER
line: Thanks for coming on such short notice. I realize the F.B.I.'s Behavioral Science Unit normally profiles murder suspects that are still at large, and it must be odd being asked to profile our suspects, all of whom are dead. I am relieved the Bureau answered our request and sent you. Because in all honesty, Agent Mulder... whatever's going on here is way over our heads. The suspect's body is out on the sidewalk. We're holding the security guard who shot him. The witnesses in the elevator are down at the hospital. You can talk to them whenever you're ready. I've asked all the businesses in the building to close for the day. We've done our best to preserve the area for you. We've thoroughly photographed the scene. The area has been sketched, but we haven't dusted for prints... yet. We wanted to wait for you before we collected further evidence.

speaker: MULDER
line: Was this damaged during the incident?

speaker: SPENCER
line: I'll find out.

speaker: MULDER
line: May I see the suspect?

speaker: SPENCER
line: Things like this aren't supposed to happen here.

speaker: MULDER
line: A forty-two year old real estate agent murders four strangers with his bare hands? That's not supposed to happen anywhere.

speaker: SPENCER
line: No. Since colonial times, there's only been three murders in this area. In the last six months, seven people have killed twenty-two. Per capita, that's higher than the combined homicide rate of Detroit, D.C. and Los Angeles. This town is not any of those places. In Franklin, you'll never have to pull off the road to make way for a celebrity driving with a gun to his head.

speaker: MULDER
line: In each incident, the suspect was killed?

speaker: SPENCER
line: Suicide by cop. Each incident occurred in a public place. The suspect went crazy and refused to desist when ordered. Officers used deadly force in order to save lives.

speaker: MULDER
line: Were autopsies conducted on the suspects for substance abuse?

speaker: SPENCER
line: Agent Mulder, this town is mainly made up of apple and cherry growers. These folks don't drink much. They certainly don't do drugs. Coroner's tests were negative. I played softball with this guy over Labor Day. He was one of those nice guys... couldn't play and didn't bitch about being stuck in right field.

speaker: MULDER
line: What's wrong with right field?

speaker: SPENCER
line: Always the first one to shake hands at the end of the game. Didn't matter whether they won or lost.

speaker: MULDER
line: Got to have an arm to play right field.

speaker: SPENCER
line: Bought a round of beers afterwards, even though he didn't drink.

speaker: MULDER
line: I played right field. Let's have this analyzed by the bureau's lab.

speaker: SPENCER
line: What the hell could bring anyone to do this?

speaker: MOTHER
line: Baby, you're bleeding. Tilt your head back. I told you to leave it alone, okay? Now, don't touch it or it'll bleed again. Tilt your head back.

speaker: MESSAGE
line: Security guard. Take his gun. Kill 'em all.

speaker: SECURITY GUARD
line: Hey! Hey, what the hell's wrong with you?

speaker: MULDER
line: Perpetrators of mass murders are divided into two classifications... the spree killer and the serial. The sudden violent outburst in a public locale and the suspect's disregard for anonymity or survival define the Franklin incidents as spree killings.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I was wondering when you'd get to that.

speaker: MULDER
line: I find no evidence of this to be the case. The single, connecting trace evidence to the killings is the destruction of an electronic device at the crime scene. A pager, a fax machine, a cellular phone, a gas pump digital display. In all honesty, Scully, I've never had a more difficult time developing a profile. There is no way to know who will be a killer... or who will be killed.

speaker: MCROBERTS
line: Hello? Hello?

speaker: MECHANIC
line: You're late.

speaker: MCROBERTS
line: I'm sorry. I called earlier. A deadline came up at work. If it's ready, I'll just pay you and... get out of here.

speaker: MECHANIC
line: How did you manage to break that anyhow?

speaker: MCROBERTS
line: Oh, it's a long story. Did you fix it?

speaker: MECHANIC
line: It's fixed.

speaker: MCROBERTS
line: What do I owe you?

speaker: MECHANIC
line: I'll tell you. In fixing that, I found some other problems. Serious problems, Mrs. McRoberts. Come back here, I'll show you.

speaker: MCROBERTS
line: I'm sorry. My husband's waiting for me. I have to go.

speaker: MECHANIC
line: Okay, but you ain't going to go very far unless you get this fixed. Come here. This is a diagnostic test of your engine. You're supposed to have an output of a hundred and sixty-eight horses at sixty-two hundred R.P.M.s. You're nowhere near that. Come over here. Next to me. I want you to take a look at this. Well, first of all, you're leaking oil like crazy. Your throw rods are chattering, valves need adjustment.

speaker: MESSAGE
line: Liar.

speaker: MECHANIC
line: And over here, you've got a couple of engine mounts that should be replaced.

speaker: MESSAGE
line: He's a liar.

speaker: MECHANIC
line: There's some arching off your coil wire... to tell you the truth, I think we should replace all the ignition wires.

speaker: MESSAGE
line: He'll rape you. He'll kill you. Kill him first.

speaker: MECHANIC
line: If you don't believe me, take a look here.

speaker: LARRY WINTER
line: Agent Mulder? Larry Winter, county supervisor.

speaker: MULDER
line: Uh, pardon my rubber.

speaker: LARRY WINTER
line: Can you tell me if... this murder is more of the same?

speaker: SPENCER
line: They don't seem to be connected.

speaker: LARRY WINTER
line: Well, should I be relieved or more scared? I mean, is this the start of copycat killers?

speaker: SPENCER
line: No, Larry, it's not a copy of the other homicides. This wasn't committed in a public area. The suspect fled, covering his tracks. And the killer appears not to have had a premeditated weapon.

speaker: MULDER
line: They are connected.

speaker: MULDER
line: Mrs. McRoberts?

speaker: MCROBERTS
line: Yes?

speaker: MULDER
line: This is Sheriff Spencer, and I'm Agent Fox Mulder with the Federal Bureau of Investigation. May we come in?

speaker: MCROBERTS
line: I'm late for work.

speaker: MULDER
line: You can blame me. Been having some car trouble?

speaker: MCROBERTS
line: That's my husband's department.

speaker: MULDER
line: May I speak with him?

speaker: MCROBERTS
line: He just took the car to Pittsburgh for a business meeting. Is it okay if I have my breakfast?

speaker: MULDER
line: It's the day's most important meal.

speaker: MESSAGE
line: He knows.

speaker: MULDER
line: Um... this invoice? It was, uh, signed by you. Did you pick up the car last night?

speaker: MESSAGE
line: Kill 'em both.

speaker: MCROBERTS
line: Yes. her food down on the counter.)

speaker: MULDER
line: Can you describe to me exactly how the dashboard read-out was damaged? Mrs. McRoberts?

speaker: MCROBERTS
line: I did it. I broke it.

speaker: MULDER
line: Why? Mrs. McRoberts? Did you see something in the read-out? Mrs. McRoberts? I can help. Mrs. McRoberts?

speaker: SPENCER
line: Stop!

speaker: MULDER
line: No!

speaker: SCULLY
line: Several anomalies were discovered in post-mortem analysis that were undetected in previous autopsies. Levels of adrenaline are known to be high in cases of violent death, twice as much as in victims of natural death. This subject's levels were two-hundred times normal. The adrenal gland displayed extensive adrenal hemorrhage, yet not from disease, but rather from wear. Other physiological evidence present indicated intense phobia. Analysis of the vitreous humor extracted from the eyeball......indicated the presence of high concentration of an undetermined chemical compound. This compound, at it's base, is similar to the substance analyzed earlier on a perpetrator's finger. Although further qualitative analysis must be performed, it is my opinion that this chemical, when reacting with adrenaline and other compounds secreted during phobic episodes, creates a substance to lysergic acid diethylamide... L.S.D.

speaker: EDWARD FUNSCH
line: Pardon me. I'd like to apply for a job.

speaker: CLERK
line: Sorry. They're not accepting applications at this time.

speaker: WOMAN
line: Sir? May we ask you to sign up for the blood drive? Sir? Are you all right? Sir?

speaker: MESSAGE
line: Behind you. Do it!

speaker: FROHIKE
line: Hmmm...

speaker: BYERS
line: In our April edition of "The Lone Gunmen," we ran an article on the C.I.A.'s new CCDTH-twenty-one thirty-eight fiber-optic-lens micro-video camera.

speaker: LANGLY
line: Small enough to be placed on the back of a fly.

speaker: MULDER
line: Imagine being one of those flies on the wall of the Oval Office.

speaker: FROHIKE
line: Been there, done that.

speaker: BYERS
line: That is a Eurasian cluster fly. They infest vegetation like, uh, apples or cherries and can inflict a great deal of damage to crops.

speaker: LANGLY
line: This one's probably been irradiated to control propagation.

speaker: BYERS
line: Or agents of competing South American agricultural corporations posing as Franklin city employees, are releasing fertile flies to destroy the crops.

speaker: FROHIKE
line: Nope. This bug's been nuked.

speaker: MULDER
line: It was a fine effort, though. Have you ever come across this chemical compound?

speaker: LANGLY
line: L.S.D.M. Obviously, you haven't read our August edition of "T.L.G."

speaker: MULDER
line: Oh, I'm sorry, boys. It arrived the same day as my subscription to "Celebrity Skin."

speaker: BYERS
line: Come over here.

speaker: FROHIKE
line: So, Mulder, where's your little partner?

speaker: MULDER
line: She wouldn't come. She's afraid of her love for you.

speaker: FROHIKE
line: She's tasty.

speaker: MULDER
line: You know, Frohike, it's men like you that give perversion a bad name.

speaker: BYERS
line: Here... toxic pesticides. The chemical you have in that report is called "lysergic dimethrin." It's an unreleased experimental synthetic botanical insecticide. It attempts to act as a natural pheromone.

speaker: LANGLY
line: L.S.D.M. is sprayed on the plant, which invokes a fear response in the pest. You know, "get out of here, there's danger." The insect reacts and leaves the plant.

speaker: MULDER
line: Why won't they release it? Is it possible it affects humans in the same way?

speaker: BYERS
line: Possible? Let me show you something.

speaker: LANGLY
line: This is actual newsreel footage taken in the 50's. They're spraying D.D.T... a chemical the government did release and determine to be safe.

speaker: BYERS
line: Thirty years later......they found out that women exposed to it had higher rates of breast cancer. They convinced local officials it was even safe to spray on children. It took a decade of bureaucratic and industry heel-dragging before it was banned.

speaker: LANGLY
line: Different chemicals, same stunts.

speaker: BYERS
line: They just learned how not to be so obvious.

speaker: MULDER
line: Hey, Frohike, can I borrow those?

speaker: FROHIKE
line: If I can have Scully's phone number.

speaker: LARRY WINTER
line: Stealth helicopters? Experimental pesticides responsible for violent behavior?

speaker: MULDER
line: I saw the chopper from two different locations. Look at my skin, feel my hair. The insecticide is still on me.

speaker: LARRY WINTER
line: I checked up on you. You have a penchant for... "Spooky" evidence.

speaker: MULDER
line: Don't start with that tired crap. Don't start diverting blame.

speaker: LARRY WINTER
line: Hang on a second here...

speaker: MULDER
line: Look, if you're the one responsible for the illegal spraying, then the sooner you take responsibility, the sooner people will stop dying. The killers all resided near heavily sprayed areas.

speaker: LARRY WINTER
line: You don't live here, Mulder. I live here. I have my heart in this town. I have three children. I'm not going to dump poison on them.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, well, if it's so safe, why was it done in secret?

speaker: LARRY WINTER
line: What kind of a crusade are you on?

speaker: SPENCER
line: Answer the question. Are we spraying?

speaker: LARRY WINTER
line: This county lives on money generated from its crops. The irradiated flies were not effective. The delays to get approval to spray would have caused millions in crop damage. Look at the hell they raised in California over malathion. Meanwhile, people's lives were being ruined by a... a damn bug.

speaker: SPENCER
line: Ruined? Twenty-three people are dead.

speaker: LARRY WINTER
line: There is no proof whatsoever of the spray caused violent behavior. It was proven to me to be safe.

speaker: MULDER
line: By who? Who proved it to you?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm sorry, Mulder, he's right. I'd love to tell you that I flew three-hundred miles in the middle of the night to perform tests that prove that you're about to become the next Charles Manson... but I find little physiological evidence that L.S.D.M. has toxically affected you... even after massive ingestion.

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully, your own autopsy reported the killer had chemical anomalies.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yes, but you are proof that it wasn't from exposure to L.S.D.M.

speaker: SPENCER
line: May I see that chart, Agent Scully?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Sure. These are normal, right here......subjected to successive L.S.D.M. sprays...

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully. Are you familiar with subliminal messages?

speaker: SCULLY
line: You mean like... sex and ice cubes in liquor in ice cube ads? That's paranoia.

speaker: MULDER
line: No, it's a fact that some department stores use subliminal messages in their ambient music to deter shoplifting. And the Russians have been using advanced electroensephelographic techniques to control behavior.

speaker: SCULLY
line: And how is this connected with the spraying?

speaker: MULDER
line: Electronic devices were destroyed by every perpetrator.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm still waiting.

speaker: MULDER
line: The insecticide L.S.D.M. is known to invoke a fear response in cluster flies. What if the chemical causes the same reaction in humans? All the perpetrators were phobic. Taber was claustrophobic. McRoberts' husband stated she had a paranoia about rape. The insecticide heightened their already existing phobia to an unbearable level. Then the electronic devices relayed messages that told them specifically what to do with their fear in order to alleviate it. The messages were relayed purposely.

speaker: SCULLY
line: By who?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, he's probably one of those people that thinks Elvis is dead.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, I was wrong. Exposure to the insecticide does induce paranoia.

speaker: MULDER
line: I think this area is being subjected to a controlled experiment.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Controlled by who? By the government? By a corporation? By Reticulans?

speaker: MULDER
line: They've done it before. D.D.T. in the 50's, Agent Orange, germ warfare on unsuspecting neighborhoods.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yes, but why, Mulder? Why would they intentionally create a populace that destroys itself?

speaker: MULDER
line: Fear. It's the oldest tool of power. If you're distracted by fear of those around you, it keeps you from seeing the actions of those above.

speaker: SPENCER
line: I just had a talk with Mister Winter. I have persuaded him to a compromise. He's agreed to stop the spraying immediately and to blood testing extensively the people exposed to the spray area.

speaker: MULDER
line: But?

speaker: SPENCER
line: But... the official explanation of the testing cannot be linked to the side-effects of L.S.D.M.

speaker: WOMAN ON TV
line: Franklin and Fanengo counties are participating in an important nationwide study on cholesterol. Volunteers will be coming to your door, or you may report at your convenience to Franklin Community General. The procedure is very simple and painless. Just a little prick on the fingertip and your participation is complete. And appreciated. So remember, cholesterol screening can save your life. So when those volunteers come to your door, answer readily, or you may report at your convenience to Franklin Community General. Thank you.

speaker: MESSAGE
line: Blood. Blood. Kill.

speaker: SPENCER
line: And your test results on the blood samples were double-checked? Are you sure? Uh-huh. Last area just reported in. Okay, these are the sectors that have tested negative. This is a list of people who, for one reason or another, haven't checked out. There's about twenty-five.

speaker: MULDER
line: Only seven more to go.

speaker: SCULLY
line: This is odd.

speaker: MULDER
line: Frustrated Jehovah's witness?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Door's unlocked.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Here it is.

speaker: MULDER
line: Edward Funsch, age fifty-two. No diploma, no vehicle or driver's license, navy radio man, wife died ten years ago. No kids. No known family, just been laid-off. Medical history?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Nothing. I mean, he hasn't seen a doctor in decades.

speaker: MULDER
line: When was the blood tester here?

speaker: SPENCER
line: About ten-thirty this morning.

speaker: MULDER
line: Ten-thirty? The blood test. I know what he's afraid of... and I know where he's going.

speaker: EDWARD FUNSCH
line: Hey, wait! Stop! Stop! Stop! Hey!

speaker: BUS DRIVER
line: All right, all right, hold on a second.

speaker: EDWARD FUNSCH
line: Funsch.

speaker: MESSAGE
line: They're waiting. Get off.

speaker: EDWARD FUNSCH
line: Pardon me.

speaker: BUS DRIVER
line: Wait for the next stop.

speaker: EDWARD FUNSCH
line: Please! I'm on the wrong bus.

speaker: BUS DRIVER
line: Wait for the next stop.

speaker: EDWARD FUNSCH
line: Open the door! Open the door! God, open the door, damn it!

speaker: MAN ON WALKIE-TALKIE
line: Uh, C-one, this is X-ray-four. Negative on that North-South line.

speaker: SPENCER
line: Copy that. If he's on it, it's going to be this line.

speaker: MULDER
line: Here it comes.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Get the uniforms out of sight.

speaker: MULDER
line: Have you seen this man?

speaker: BUS DRIVER
line: Yeah, I picked him off. Drove four feet, then he went apewire.

speaker: MULDER
line: Where'd you let him out?

speaker: BUS DRIVER
line: Near the college.

speaker: SCULLY
line: We'll have to wait him out.

speaker: MULDER
line: I don't think he's waiting.

speaker: MESSAGE
line: Up.

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully, anything?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Nothing.

speaker: SPENCER
line: Get down! Get down!

speaker: MULDER
line: Get down! Get down! Get down!

speaker: SPENCER
line: Please remain calm! Stay away from the building!

speaker: EDWARD FUNSCH
line: I've seen that all and I've seen that and I don't want to see that again, baby.

speaker: SPENCER
line: All units, forthwith, Franklin College. Shots fired. Send emergency vehicles.

speaker: MULDER
line: Put it down! Put it down!

speaker: EDWARD FUNSCH
line: Don't kill me.

speaker: MULDER
line: Then put it down, Ed.

speaker: EDWARD FUNSCH
line: I can't. They won't let me.

speaker: MULDER
line: I know they won't, Ed. I know they won't let you.

speaker: EDWARD FUNSCH
line: Then... you make me put it down, then. You do it.

speaker: MULDER
line: If you don't put it down, I'm going to have to shoot you. Or you're going to have to shoot me. There's going to be blood... everywhere.

speaker: EDWARD FUNSCH
line: They'll kill me.

speaker: MULDER
line: It's all right.

speaker: SPENCER
line: Agent Scully will examine him at the hospital. You can call her there.

speaker: MULDER
line: I want unrestricted access to him for questioning.

speaker: SPENCER
line: Mulder... you know more about what happened to him than he does.

speaker: MESSAGE
line: All done. Bye-bye.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Scully. Hello? Mulder, is that you? Mulder, where are you? Mulder? Mulder, where are you?
